the Iraq war came in drawing down troops too quickly. ''I don't have enough confidence to say that that's right. I think that it's possible,'' he said. We had[ an] enormous number of troops ready to go in. They had- we had off-ramps, if they weren't needed. He added: ''It's hard to know. You know, the path you didn't take is always smoother.'' on ''too many hands on the steering wheel.'' Donald Rumsfeld , who served as President Bush 's defense chief for six years after holding the the same job under president Gerald Ford in the 1970s, acknowledged that in a war, many things cost lives. But he had no regrets about his leadership of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan-- the latter now nearing its 10th anniversary. He refused to echo the regrets of another

He proposed a different strategy: ''grind down'' Saddam Hussein through a policy of containment or strangulation. April Glaspie met with Saddam Hussein on July 25, 1990. of Evansville political science professor. If Mike Pence is to encounter any bumps at all, they could come early, as he shifts his focus from federal to state issues, Robert Dion said. There's going to be that transition that might have a few hiccups to it, he said.
